notes:
Company email (January 2017)
"No, I really don’t use any gel or isinglass these days. Used to on occasion, but not anymore. I fine whites with Benotnite for cold stability. Benonite is an earth material, like a clay."

Company Email (circa 2011)
"I rarely use fining agents of these kinds in conjunction with filtration. I used to use more of them, but over time simply found them to be unnecessary.

As far as ingredients go, really the only ingredient is grapes, unless we need to hydrate a must with water to avoid an inordinately high alcohol. I don’t consider yeast to be an ingredient per se, and even if it were, it’s there naturally in every juice; what ever is added beyond that is done so to bolster what’s already there. We will fortify a must now and then with nutrients for the yeast, which is like giving the juice vitamins. There is some nitrogen in that yeast food, and I am not sure what the source of it is. I can contact the supplier if like to ask them.

We do use bentonite (an earth/clay material) in fining of the whites to stabilize the surplus of proteins that they precipitate out otherwise.

And, of course, we do employ some sulfite as a preservative."

The only products we use during the clarification are:
 
PVPP: to avoid the colour evolution, PVPP (a polymer) is added to the wine which reacts with the unstable colouring matter
 
Bentonite: bentonite (clay) is added. The bentonite has the capacity of joining itself to the proteins."

notes:
Company email (January 2011):
"All Bonny Doon wines are currently vegan; we use no animal products in the winemaking process. Some wineries use albumin, milk, or isinglass as fining agents to clarify their wines, but we currently use only bentonite clay. 
We don't rule out the possibility of using these ingredients if a particular wine in a particular vintage really needed this treatment. However, our winery pioneered ingredient labeling, so if we ever did choose to use them, we would disclose the items used on the back label. (As you're probably aware, wineries are not required to list ingredients.)
You may be interested in this article on vegan wines that was published last week:
http://www.thekitchn.com/thekitchn/wine/vegan-wine-what-is-it-and-how-can-i-find-vegan-wines--136676
The article specifically names Bonny Doon Vineyard as a vegan-friendly winery."

Company Email:
"Bonny Doon Vineyard does not use any animal ingredients in our winemaking practices, and have not for at least five years. We use bentonite in the fining process, but not isinglass, milk, or albumin. While we don't rule out the possibility of using these if a wine truly needed it (each vintage presents its separate challenges), but if we were to use any, we would include them in our full-disclosure ingredient labeling on the back label."

Company Email (June 2007):
"Even though we try to be as ethical as viticultually possible, I'm sorry to say, our wines are for the most part not vegan.

Some of our red wines may be vegan as we normally do not filter or fine our reds. However, there are instances when we use either skim milk or egg whites as fining agents to remove microscopic particles that could cloud the wines. But to be on the safe side, our wines overall cannot be guaranteed vegan.

"Como sabes existen productos clarificantes de origen animal pero también de origen mineral, como la bentonita (arcilla de grano muy fino, y uno de los más utilizados en la actualidad), el carbón activo o el gel de sílice. El proceso de clarificación no se lleva a cabo en todos los vinos, como es el caso de nuestros vinos tintos, los cuales se filtran pero no se clarifican. En el caso de los blancos se clarifican son bentonita. Son por tanto aptos para veganos."

[Google translate: "As you know there are fining animal products but also of mineral, such as bentonite (clay of very fine grain, and one of the most used today), activated carbon or silica gel. The clarification process is not performed in all wines , as is the case of our red wines, which are filtered but not clarified. In the case of white bentonite they are clarified. They are therefore suitable for vegans."]

During the elaboration of our wines we only use product of mineral origin (e.g. bentonite, which is used to clarify the grape juice). city: Eugenio Bustos. CP 5569. San Carlos. Mendoza
notes:
Translation from Michelle:
"In our wines are not additives or adjuvants which are derived from
milk, eggs, or animal component, as well as those not specifically
mentioned: gelatin, isinglass, etc..
 All inputs are derived from natural winemaking in the same industry
in wine (tartaric acid, cream of tartar), yeasts and bacteria selected
(non-GMO), cellulose derivatives (for filtration).

 Therefore, all our wines are suitable for consumption by vegetarians
and vegans."

Company Email:
En nuestros vinos no se utilizan aditivos ni coadyuvantes que sean
derivados de la leche, huevos, o cualquier componente animal, como así
tampoco los que mencionás específicamente: gelatina, ictiocola, etc.
Todos los insumos enológicos son derivados naturales de la misma
industria del vino (ácido tartárico, cremor tártaro), levaduras y
bacterias seleccionadas (libres de OGM), derivados de la celulosa
(para filtración).

Por lo tanto, todos nuestros vinos son aptos para ser consumidos por
vegetarianos y veganos.

Estamos a tu disposición por cualquier consulta o comentario adicional."

dev.normalized_name: grupo la rioja alta s a
notes:
Company email (May 2013):
"Lo primero agradecerte el haberte puesto en contacto con nosotros a través del formulario de la página web. Estamos encantados de contestarte y poder ayudarte, aportándote los datos que necesitas sobre los productos que utilizamos en la elaboración de nuestros vinos.

Los vinos que elabora La Rioja Alta nunca contienen ninguno de los productos que mencionas, no utilizamos para la clarificación de nuestros vinos ningún producto de origen animal, ni siquiera derivados como ovoalbúmina, ictiocola, … Puedes tranquilizar a los vegetarianos y veganos en este sentido, porque los vinos de La Rioja Alta se elaboran, como es lógico, con uva como materia prima y, durante su elaboración se les adiciona, siempre que sea necesario, sulfitos para garantizar su adecuada conservación (mención que figura en todas las etiquetas). Para la clarificación utilizamos bentonitas, que nada tienen que ver con origen animal".

[Google translation] "I thank you for putting you first contact us via the form on the website.'re Pleased to answer you and help you, providing you the information you need about the products we use in winemaking.

Wines La Rioja Alta produces never contain any of the products you mentioned, not used to the clarification of our wines any animal product, even as ovalbumin derivatives, isinglass, ... You can reassure vegetarians and vegans in this sense, because the wines of La Rioja Alta are made, of course, with grapes as raw material and its preparation were added, when necessary, sulfites to ensure proper conservation (reference under all labels). For clarification we use bentonites, that have nothing to do with animal."

notes:
Company Email from the actual winery:

"It is not the first time we get this question. In fact, it is kind of frequent. You are right during the fining/filtering is when you might get animal products interfering the making process. We do not use any of those. What we use for filtering is bentonite (I hope this is the English word for the substance). Therefore your customer can be certain that if he/she drinks any of our wines, she/he can be a proper vegan."


Company Email from Vineyard Brands who resell this wine: 
"Bentonite is a clay, commonly used in filtering wines.  So I think you can enjoy your bottle of Crianza without reservation.  So far we have not compiled a list of suppliers who don't use any animal products but I will see what I can find out about that."

address: C/ Torrea 1, 01340 Elciego (Álava) [Elciego Winery] and Crtra. Nacional VI, Km. 172,600. 47490 - Rueda (Valladolid) [Rueda Winery]
notes:
Company email (June 2016):
"We do not use any of the products you mention for the filtering process. Our clarification process is naturally made by means of long barrel ageing (24-26 months) and, once wine is stabilized, it is sent to a plate filter before bottling. Thus, we avoid aggressive filtering that may produce a loss in wine character."

Company email (May 2013):
"Los vinos elaborados por Bodegas Marques de Riscal son elaborados a partir de uvas procedentes de nuestros viñedos y de proveedores de las localidades de Elciego, Navaridas, Leza y Laguardia, principalmente.

Durante el proceso de elaboración no se incorpora ningún tipo de aditivo, excepto sulfitos, con objeto de que no se desarrolle la actividad de microorganismos, que pudieran alterar la calidad de nuestros vinos.

No se emplea ningún otro aditivo, no necesitándose clarificantes ni estabilizantes por los periodos de crianza de nuestros vinos en barrica, realizándose estos procesos de forma natural"

[Google translation] "The wines produced by Bodegas Marques de Riscal are made ​​from grapes from our vineyards and suppliers Elciego localities, Navaridas, Leza and Laguardia, mainly.

During the development process does not incorporate any additives, except sulphites, to not develop the activity of microorganisms, which could alter the quality of our wines.

Does not use any other additives, not needing clarifying and stabilizing for the periods of aging of our wines in barrel, performing these processes naturally"

Company email (October 2011):
"I’m glad to inform you that the Winery Marqués de Riscal doesn’t use for the filtration or clarification of our wines any of the products mentioned in your email.

The clarification is a natural process and we make it by ageing our wines in barrels for a long period of time (between 24 and 26 months). Once the wines are stabilized we make a very simple filtration before bottling them. We try to avoid aggressive filtrations that only may damage the character of our wines."

notes:
Company email (June 2012):
"Respecto a su consulta, le debemos indicar que nosotros no contamos con certificación de productos Veganos ya que no existe una que sea internacionalmente aceptada y confiable (o al menos no la conocemos), por lo pronto nosotros manejamos el 100% de nuestros campos de manera Orgánica de los cuales la principal línea de comercialización en este rango lleva por nombre Las Mulas.

Por otro lado, en la actualidad nosotros no utilizamos en la clarificación de ninguno de nuestros vinos proteínas procedentes de animales como lo son la albúmina, caseína ni ictiocola, en su reemplazo utilizamos clarificaciones por frío y como co-ayudantes enzimas de origen microbiano. Ninguno de los otros insumos enológicos utilizados en la vinificación de nuestros productos son de origen animal."

[Google translation]: "Regarding your request, we indicate that we do not have certified Vegan product and there is no internationally accepted to be reliable (or at least we do not know), so soon we handle 100% of our fields so organic which the main line of marketing in this range bears the name Las Mulas. Moreover, at present we do not use in the clarification of any of our wines from animal proteins such as albumin, casein or isinglass, in replacement for cold clarification used as co-enzymes of microbial origin assistants. None of the other inputs used in wine making winemaking of our products are of animal origin."

notes:
Company email (November 2017) re Dom Perignon
"We can confirm that all our products are vegan."

Company email (January 2013):
"Our Oenology Department has just confirmed us that we do not use any animal products in the making of our champagnes."

From Erin, January 2012:
"I just wanted to say that unfortunately Moet is not vegan. My parents visited the cellars, and I was looking forward to getting a present as I love champagne but all they came back was with insider info - their tour guide confirmed none of their products were vegan. As I wasn't there I can't confirm what exactly they asked but just wanted to let you know."

Company email:
We confirm you that our Champagne is only made with grapes and is gluten and wheat free and without animal or eggs products.

You can taste and drink it without problem.

"Le confermo che il Marche Trebbiano Moncaro può essere bevuto sia da vegetariani sia da vegani in quanto non contiene nessun ingrediente di origine animale né vengono usate sostanze di derivazione animale durante la sua lavorazione."

notes:
Company email (June 2015): (Via del Campo Rosado)
"Vad spännande med en vegan-vänlig guide om viner! Intresset och medvetenheten kring viner har ökat på senare år, vilket är viktigt och bra för både vinbranschen och konsumenten!
Vad gäller vårt vin Via del Campo Rosado, så använder vi på NSW inga animaliska produkter vid produktionen. Produkten tillverkas på en och samma plats, dvs här på NSW i Simrishamn, dock kan tillvägagångssätten och produktionstiden ändras lite från gång till gång i och med att egenskaperna hos vinet kan skilja sig från leverans till leverans samt från årgång till årgång. Tillverkningsprocessen av vinet är ett hantverk och bestäms utifrån de specifika egenskaperna hos det aktuella vinet."

[Translation by Louise] "How exciting with a vegan-friendly guide about wines! The interest and awareness of the wines has increased in recent years, which is important and good for both the trade and the consumer!
As for our wine Via del Campo Rosado, at the NSW we don’t use any animal products in the production. The product is manufactured at the same location, ie here at NSW in Simrishamn, however, the  course of action and production time changes little from time to time as the characteristics of the wine can vary from delivery to delivery, and from vintage to vintage. The manufacturing process of the wine is a craft and is determined based on the specific characteristics of the wine."

notes:
Company Email:
"I recently discovered your site thanks to Twitter and would like to invite you to learn about Querciabella, a biodynamic wine estate located in Tuscany's legendary Chianti Classico zone. We not only have the privilege of producing some of the region's most critically acclaimed wines, but also we pride ourselves in leading the way for conservationism in viticulture. What this means at Querciabella is that respect for the environment and animal life is central to the way we work during all phases of wine growing and production.

While Querciabella has long been a benchmark of sustainability, converting to organic viticulture in 1988 and subsequently transitioning to biodynamics in 2000, the winery's owner Sebastiano Cossia Castiglioni, an outspoken animal rights activist, decided to ban all animal-derived products from the estate in 2007. As a result of our rigorous 100% Vegan policy, we have eliminated the use of animal products not only from the cellar but from the vineyards as well, relying exclusively on the use of cover crops for soil management"

notes:
Company email (March 2016)
"All of our wines are suitable for vegans."

Company email (June 2015)

"Emiliana's wine are organic and biodynamic, which means we use no kind of animal-by products. So yes, our wines are vegan friendly."

Company email (April 2015)

"Emiliana's wines are suitable for vegans. We don't use any animal ingredients or products in the process what so ever and they're only bottle in Chile."

Company email:
"For our fining process we used betonies. For the filtering we used for our wines 4 to 6 micron filter and we do 3 to 4 racking back to get the big sediments out of the barrels. Under the IMO regulation we cannot used any type of animal product such as albumins, gelatins, etc. Honey and milk are products that are not used on winemaking."

Company email:
"In Emiliana there are not wines with animal ingredients. The range Natura is made with organically grown grapes, with commercial and native yeast and the stabilization process is made naturally."

"I am happy to confirm that the Dr. L Riesling is suitable for vegans. No animal products are used in its production. The only filtration we do is with diatomaceous earth. And the wine is all bottled by us at our winery in the Mosel."

products_found_at_vinmonopolet.Metode: Druene ferm. i rustfri ståltank. Vinen pumpes over to ganger daglig. 16md på eikefat og ståltank.
products_found_at_vinmonopolet.Rastoff: Cabernet Sauvignon 80%, Petit Verdot 8%, Malbec 5%, Petite Syrah 5%, Tempranillo (Tinto del Pais) 2%
products_found_at_vinmonopolet.Smak: God konsentrasjon, fylde og balanserte tanniner.

products_found_at_vinmonopolet.Lagringsgrad: Drikkeklar nå, men kan også lagres
products_found_at_vinmonopolet.Lukt: Delikate aromaer av mørk frukt som kirsebær og modne bringebær. Hint av kakao.
products_found_at_vinmonopolet.Metode: Ferm. separat i ståltanker. Presses etter 7-12 dgr m skall. Lagres 24 md på franske, øst-europeiske, nøytrale eikefat.
products_found_at_vinmonopolet.Rastoff: Merlot 85%, Petite Syrah 8%, Petit Verdot 4%, Cabernet Sauvignon 3%
products_found_at_vinmonopolet.Smak: Balansert med middels lette tanniner, hint av modne røde bær og lett syrlig avslutning.
